Definition: In this job, your task is to categorize a statement, received from online platforms, into one of two categories: threat or non-threat. Threatening someone means implying that someone will be hurt even if they do not do something specific.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: He should be executed, not given 48 years.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Opening up people of a different race to violent acts including death by idiots, by inciting her followers to violence, is offensive. If anything happens to the Jones family, Dembroski should be charged as an accessory.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but is not a threat to anyone.

Anyone and everyone. This is a community problem, so everyone who wants to be part of the solution should be allowed to help. As I said above: remove all protections on free ranging cats, and allow people to help. People who allow their pets to roam outside are part of the problem, because their pets are part of the problem. It would be very sad if pets were killed, but ultimately it is the owner's responsibility to make sure their pets are not out killing birds.

Years ago some Vermont acquaintances got one warning from the Ranger: Next time I see your dog running deer, I'll shoot it. Next time she saw it running deer, she did. 

Vermont does not pretend that trapping, neutering, and releasing dogs solves any problems. They are serious about threats. We just want to feel good about ourselves. If we were serious about feral cats, we would kill them. Neutered cats eat birds. Don't release them. Kill them.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: If you think putting Alaska Natives in charge of ANY natural resource will provide any degree of protection or conservation, you apparently do not read much. You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Comment: The amount of power loss in transmission lines is related to the voltage with P=IV. V=IR so P=RI^2.  For AC resistance is replaced with impedance (z) which involves the resistance as well as capacitance and inductance. For long distance transmission of electricity DC is favored because there is less capacitive and inductive loss and because there is no need to synchronize as in AC. DC voltage changes are less efficient than AC with a transformer so that need to be part of the consideration.
For low current solid state devices the use of 12-36 volts could use in a circuit for such device. Rooftop PV system usually have an output voltage of around 300 V.  Many minigrds run of a 380VDC standard.

But having said what he said so openly, we can reasonably expect action from Francis in the foreseeable future. So we wait again and watch.

What I find puzzling in the case of the Ontario sites next to pipelines is that we have clarity: the PPS and the 200 metre setback established by TSSA clearly prohibit what's going on, the most recent example being a 28-storey apartment currently being built next to five high-pressure pipelines.

Comment: A lifetime friend of mine, sadly now deceased, came over as a visiting professor to a Canadian university in the 1980s to mark papers in economics. He failed everyone, and was hauled into the dean's office and told that he couldn't do that. "But none of them deserved to pass. They don't know the basics.", he replied. It didn't matter. He returned to Lausanne in Switzerland and continued to mark according to merit.

Comment: Repudiation of the Doctrine of Discovery... Part 2

John Marshall, who is most credited with describing the doctrine, did not voice wholehearted support of the doctrine even while using it to justify judicial decisions. He pointed to the doctrine as simple fact, looking at the possession-takings which had been supported by it as things which had occurred and had to be recognized. The supposedly inferior character of native cultures was a reason for the doctrine having been used, but whether or not that was justified was not relevant for Marshall.

This Doctrine governs United States Indian Law today and has been cited as recently as 2005 in the decision City Of Sherrill V. Oneida Indian Nation Of N.Y.

 So when nearly 600 clergy and religious turn out to "stand with" Standing Rock it is an acknowledgement of the legitimacy of Native American Religious Freedom and a Repudiation
of the Doctrine of Discovery.

It is repudiation of Presumptive Power over Native American Freedom of Religion

Comment: Alaskans, check your freezers, I had 7 bags of the products in question. The odd thing, I noticed a odor of bad food when I opened the top of my refrigerator freezer and have wondered what that was for about a week.  I checked my fridge and could not find any "bad" food and I could not think where the odor was coming from, least of all frozen food. I even moved my fridge out to see if a food item some how got behind it and that was not the case. Listeria is a bacteria that is not killed off by freezing and can grow in the freezer and refrigerator. I cleaned out my freezer , using gloves and wrapped the contaminated products into leak proof bags before I disposed of them. I did not need to clean out my big freezer since I did not have the recalled frozen fruits and vegetables in that one. My fridge and freezer this morning smells clean and fresh for the first time in a number of weeks. I should have investigated the bad odor in the freezer more as soon as I smelled it.

Comment: @SRWU, Car companies could care less whether they sell ICE or EV as long as they can sell what they produce. Economics 101, supply and demand. The issue with electric is there's no demand making production at scale a waste of resources with current technology. Back in the 90s, California tried to legislate how many ZEVs had to be sold. They wanted to gradually increase the numbers to 10% of vehicles sold by 2003 but the legislation had to be rescinded because despite incentives, sales were anemic and still are. 

For a variety of reasons, principally range and charging infrastructure, there's still only a minority of consumers that can justify owning an EV, especially if it's their only vehicle and until that changes, EVs are a luxury, not a necessity. Until your EV is capable of making all of the trips that your ICE vehicle can, rather than just the short trips around town, it's a niche product.

Comment: A big player in perceptions about what is afoot within the Church today is the electronic media age which did not exist at the time of VII.   For many years all we knew was what might trickle down from the RCC  'on high' to our local parish level.   We now know from the written records of events back then that there was plenty of ugly in-fighting and name-calling among various factions,  from hard-line traditionalists to progressive camps of bishops... but it was not common knowledge at the time.   Pope Francis is old enough to have the long-view perspective that some younger folks might not.   The institutional church has always been fractious because it is full of flawed humans both laity and clergy...  and that includes ALL of us,  including those convinced they are the only ones with the capital-T truth.

Comment: A project of this size and expense should last for generations; when the first urban subways were constructed in several east coast cities, they were state of the art, betting on a new, not yet proven technology of electrification. They excited the people, and enabled transportation around and outside the city, creating suburbs and new economic activity.

Our rail, more than a century later, is unlikely to be useful even a few decades from now. The modern equivalent to electrification is self driving vehicles taking people point to point, eliminating the need for garages, car ownership, and vastly improving the utility of our road networks. Even the biggest rail supports could not honestly argue that anyone is excited about the current state of the project.

Too bad no one in government has the fortitude to rethink the entire project, and go find companies that want to use our island as a proving ground for a 21st century mode of transport.

Comment: Ronin: The U.S.C. I referred to does more than "refer specifically to contributions or donations of money." There is another phrase, the crucial phrase in the statute as far as Fredo is concerned and which you are selectively ignoring, and that phrase  is “other thing of value.” Information is an “other thing of value.” 

 “To the extent you’re using the resources of a foreign country to run your campaign — that’s an illegal campaign contribution,” according to Nick Akerman, an assistant special prosecutor during the Watergate investigation who now specializes in data crime.

Here’s the second important passage of the statute: “No person shall knowingly solicit, accept, or receive from a foreign national any contribution or donation.” The word "solicit" is why it doesn’t matter if Fredo actually got useful information. The part that’s illegal is trying to acquire information from a foreign source, whether or not the solicitation is  successful.

Comment: "Eminent domain can only be applied within your jurisdiction" Respectfully, you are incorrect. Comment: Non sequitur: The Church may very well have received magisterial authority from Christ; but even if Christ "cannot err" (which btw has to be demonstrated; you seem to take it as axiomatic), it does not follow that the Church cannot err -- unless you wish to assert that with the authority to teach comes all the content of any future teaching, a bizarre shift in the meaning of "authority."

As for slavery, etc., whatever you wish to say about "Christ Himself," the historical Jesus was an apocalyptic prophet, who expected the eschaton after only a brief wait, and so was not interested in reforming society, as though society was expected to persist for a long time. There were all kinds of subjects, ethical and other, about which he had little or no interest. So to assign to "Christ Himself" direct authority for teachings and judgments that Christians later devised for themselves, however fine, is fanciful and fictitious: defensible perhaps, but hardly to be imposed as a criterion.

Comment: Commenter makes an egregious mistake - "Drawing an equivalence between George Washington and Robert E. Lee because they both owned slaves completely ignores the fact that one led the rebellion that started our country, and the other one led a failed treasonous rebellion aimed at splitting it."  Robert E. Lee was not the commanding general of Confederate forces at the outbreak of war in April 1861.  Secondly, Virginia was late in joining the Confederacy, and Lee was very late in making up his mind which group to join.  The fact that he and his wife had family connections to George Washington also made his decision difficult.  (I recommend  The Man Who Would Not Be Washington by Jonathan Horn).  The Union Army had a great deal of respect for Lee as evidenced by their treatment of his wife when she was captured, and with the capture of his son.  I join a group of historians who argue that the destruct button was pushed with the adoption of the Constitution and those two bitter clauses.

Comment: @Cosmic Wheels: Please note that I'm not saying that time the time you referenced was EASY (I'm assuming it was the early 1980s based on you citing 14% rates). 

That said, as hard as that time was, I think it has become harder to establish yourself today than it was then. Why? Because you can't save for anything effectively anymore.

Back when there were high rates, if I delayed buying anything, my savings in a basic savings account might grow faster than the price of that thing would appreciate. In particular, I'm talking about down payments as a % of the total cost of buying a piece of real estate. 

Back then, sacrifice meant you could amass a larger % down payment each year you saved. Real estate across the board was a lower multiple of incomes and was typically growing at a far lower rate than it has in many markets over the last 10-15 years.

Each year you delay buying to save now, you fall further behind. That is a messed up dynamic that does not bode well for young people.

Comment: The Second Amendment is quite clear.  There are two parts.  One, the militia clause requires an armed militia, which we consider the National Guard, but also covers much more.  A constitutional militia is not just the construct of gov't and we are allowed to form militias as We the People see fit.  The Second also provides for the redress of a tyrannical gov't by force of arms. Comment: What we call SkyTrain in BC, is 1) a proprietary railway which patents are owned by Bombardier and SNC Lavalin and 2) a truncated heavy rail metro (Canada Line) which phony P-3 consortium is headed by SNC Lavalin.

The ALRT/ART SkyTrain lines are not considered legitimate rapid transit and only 7 such systems have been built in 40 years under various names;, ICTS. ALRT, ALM, ART.

Due to small platform size and small trains, the ART/ALRT Lines are legally only allowed to carry up to 15,000 pphpd. The Canada line, with station platforms half the length of the ALRT/ART Lines effectively has half the capacity.

The cost to increase capacity on the ALRT/ART Lines - $3 billion; on the Canada Line $1.5 billion.

Today, modern LRT can carry more customers at a much cheaper cost (see Ottawa).

Comment: The solution, quite simply, is transit. Buses running in dedicated lanes on all of the main arterials, and a few rail lines where it makes sense. The traffic lights can be programmed to make sure the buses never have to stop anywhere except the stations. I'm not against cars, but they become problematic in urban areas since they just don't scale well. If highway demand doubles, the highway width must be doubled, costing hundreds of millions and requiring extensive ROW acquisitions. If demand along a bus line doubles, well, you just run the buses ever 5 minutes instead of every 10. Problem solved. We'll still need cars to get around in general, but for commuting, when everyone needs to get somewhere at the same time, transit can't be beat.

Comment: I am an avid motorcycle rider - commute daily.  I also rode a motorcycle in the UK some years ago.  I absolutely agree that lane splitting and or lane filtering is not a good option for Canada.  The population of our drivers are not motorcycle savvy and neither our the bulk of our motorcycle riders.  In Europe splitting and filtering is a common accepted practise - but bikes have also been part of the commuter traffic for decades.  In Canada motorcycles are not necessarily for "necessity" but for recreation - we do only ride half the year in most parts!  Allowing lane splitting or filtering in Canada in my opinion would increase negative interactions with motor vehicles and there would be little gain to the environment as a result.  Just take a look at the average engine size and bike size in Canada vs. Europe.

Comment: I, personally, cannot imagine a world without movie theaters.  My first job was in a historic theater, where I watched, and participated in, the social experience created by The Exorcist! People were shocked, actually, threw up and, sometimes,fainted as EMTs rushed in to bring them back to consciousness.  Movies express past, present and, even, future possibilities for mankind. Watching, together, we are transported...and we dream, we are horrified, we find hope and joy, laughter, tears and anger.  Movies bring people together on a deep level; even a theater of strangers find camaraderie in hating the bad guy and cheering on the good guy.  
The big screen cannot be replaced in creating the overall experience  that the producers intended.  And, the best part, there are no distractions at the theater.  The movie becomes our world for 90 minutes...and we become part of its world.  That's unthinkable at home! 
Thank you for keeping movie theaters alive.  I will always be an avid supporter.

Comment: The root of this argument is:  "the simple difference between private and public sector jobs... the private sector feeds the bucket and the public sector empties it" 
That is a "simple difference" as described, but it's much more complicated than that. 
I agree that the private sector creates wealth, as in value added. Iron ore becomes steel, steel becomes cars, cars give mobility, etc. But the public sector also regulates value added, so that mining is safer, steel smelters don't pollute as much and cars are safer/less polluting. "Wealth" is that left after deducting external costs. Many companies don't pay for external costs of their products. We do.
Some of the bucket is emptied by funding regulation and part is emptied paying for services. Police, fire, streets, lights, healthcare and housing for the indigent, schools, and yes, some questionable expenditures. But this money spent is largely returned to the community. 
In this case, oversimplification is mischaracterization.

Comment: Check out Yoshoku, or Japanese takes on western foods. Ketchup spaghetti, ketchup rice in omelettes, deep fried burgers, etc.  People against 'cultural appropriation' always seem to forget that cultures mix at the edges and exchange. It's never a one way trip.  Some of those reverse trips are just as revolting as par boiled rice. 

One interesting yoshoku dish is kareraisu, or curried rice. The British picked it up in the Raj, diplomats took it with them when they traveled in the late 1800s, Japanese chefs in 'western' restaurants learned to make it and put their own spin on it, and now it's a staple of Japanese cuisine. Far from 'appropriating' it, the British fostered its spread around the globe.

Comment: The 2% figure is based on OPEC sleight of hand. The real number is closer to 1%, and with likely cheating will be below that. 

While the OPEC claim that it will cut production by 1.2 mb/d is accurate, what is not getting reported much is that 700,000 mb/d of that came from Indonesia leaving the organization, and most of the remainder is coming from Saudi Arabia. 

However, the Indonesian barrels don't  disappear from world oil production, they are just shifted from the OPEC column to the non-OPEC column. So the real reduction in world production from OPEC agreement is about 500,000 mb/d. Add the additional 550,000 or so from the weekend agreement with Russia, and that gives just over 1 mb/d in actual cuts to world production. 

That's about 1% of the 80 mb/d in world production, about half of your estimate - if no one cheats.

Comment: From the paper from which that map was developed:

"Based on the climatic conditions of those lethal heat events, we identified a global threshold beyond which daily mean surface air temperature and relative humidity become deadly. Around 30% of the world’s population is currently exposed to climatic conditions exceeding this deadly threshold for at least 20 days a year. By 2100, this percentage is projected to increase to ~48% under a scenario with drastic reductions of greenhouse gas emissions and ~74% under a scenario of growing emissions. An increasing threat to human life from excess heat now seems almost inevitable, but will be greatly aggravated if greenhouse gases are not considerably reduced."

Comment: Lizzie,

The CDC collects all that data already.  It's called WISQARs, publicly available info. CDC can, and does, research "gun violence." They are simply forbidden from doing research designed from the start to promote gun control. Which is what they were doing, beginning with the false premise that legal gun ownership is a social health program and designing studies to prove it, that got the funding restriction, not ban, enacted in the first place.

Further, there is more public health based gun research going on in this country than ever, with funding from a multitude of public and private sources. Of course, gun violence isn't a public health problem, it is a crime problem, so CDC is not really an appropriate agency to do such research, and doctors have little to no expertise in, nor demonstrated familiarity with, the subject.  Which is why the best research is being done by the actual subject matter experts: economists, sociologists, criminologists, and law enforcement academics.

Comment: Everybody talks about rates and loopholes (deductions), but very few try to identify how income is to be calculated.  For the salaried worker, it is simple.  But, for the small business owner, it can get very complicated very quickly.  How does one get from gross income to net income?  What expenses should be subtracted?

Then, another area of the tax code that is very complicated, is defining who qualifies as a dependent?  Once again, for most taxpayers, this is simple.  But when one starts to review the possibilities, it becomes complicated and a mistake can easily be made.

For a large majority of tax payers, the above cause no problems.  However, there is still a large percentage of taxpayers that have to deal with these issues.  There may not be an easy way to simplify the tax code for these taxpayers.

Comment: You are either unaware of or ignoring a significant fact.  A huge proportion of these plea deal situations are not an arrest and a single offense situation.  

Many of them are where a person commits a murder, an assault on someone else and a kidnapping on a third etc.  Many others are where a serial burglar gets arrested on 7 or 8 burglaries, car clouts, etc. and so there are numerous crimes with multiple victims.

Even if convicted on every single crime using police and judicial resources each and every time, the sentencing system will very seldom stack sentence on sentence on sentence.

Instead, the guy gets a longer sentence on one of his convictions and the others are served 'concurrently"  --- a waste of time and resources.  If the DA cuts a deal and the criminal gets that longer sentence without the numerous trials, that works for the system.

The alternative - trying everyone for everything means you have to at least quadruple the money you spend on prosecution.  Won't happen!

Comment: You obviously have very little understanding of mathematics in the real world. Every measurement, and so every prediction, has a margin of error. As an example, the trajectories of spacecraft that are not under power are extremely predictable. However, measurements of course and speed are never perfectly accurate. The result is that when NASA launches a spacecraft for Mars, it is sent, as accurately as possible, in a precisely calculated direction at a precisely calculated speed that should take it to Mars at a known time on a course and at a speed that will allow it to be injected into Mars orbit with minimum fuel burn. However, there are margins of error, which result in the need for course corrections; those course corrections do not prove that NASA's model is flawed. 

The same principle applies to climate science, except that the margins of error are, in percentage terms, larger.

It takes a tremendous amount of constant effort to keep non-profits in operation. I worked for a non-profit once, and we had to request grant money every year from the same people/organizations.  I would not be at-all surprised to see that organization go by the wayside soon.  The result will be fewer-an-fewer places for people to go to get sorely-needed help.

Comment: "The difference between willingly risking one’s life and health in service of country and risking one’s life and health for the profits of tobacco companies is vast."

I do not know a single person who smokes for the express benefit of tobacco companies in the same way they serve in the military for the benefit of their country. Usually they smoke because they like to smoke. The RG's comparison is absurdly unhelpful.

I hate smoking, particularly when my neighbor does so on his porch for an hour at dawn, and his smoke drifts in my window as I try to cool my house. Even so, I prefer people have the right to make the decision to smoke for themselves once they are of reasonable age to know the consequences, which they certainly should by 18. However, they should not be able to force others to bear any part of the costs of that decision. Tobacco should be taxed at a rate to cover all health costs for its use. Those taxes should be held in a superfund which would reimburse health providers.

Comment: I agree with you - my husband and I both work on the slope and would fall into he highest tax bracket since we have no kids. We already pay very high taxes with few deductions, contrary to the popular belief that higher wage earners have lots of tax loopholes. 
The permanent fund is extra income for Alaskans so that should be the first place to reduce or eliminate temporarily. Meanwhile the state needs to reduce spending just like all of the oil companies have done on the slope to balance their P&L's. And yes, it means sacrifice. For the companies on the slope it meant cutting jobs and wages, drastically reducing catering services, selling assets, renegotiating contracts, streamlining etc. 
The bottom line is that everyone was affected and everyone sacrificed from entry level employees to management. All Alaskans should be expected to have some skin in the game, not just those of us who work.

Comment: Regarding the abolition of the estate tax: During his campaign Trump stated that along with dropping the estate tax, he would also get rid of step up valuation at the time of death. Under current law, if your parent dies and leaves you the long time family home  and you sell it, your basis in the home is the value of it on the day they died, rather than what they bought it for.  This means that you will not show a gain from the sale and will have no taxable income from it. If Trump sticks to his plan to get rid of the ability to step up the basis, then when you sell the home that your parents bought a couple decades ago, you will likely show a significant taxable gain. Of course, Trump has also talked about getting rid of the capital gains tax at every income level, so in that case no one pays anything... This is something to watch as they reshape the tax code, as for many the only real asset they have is their home and it could be a downward shift in taxes.

Our Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Lester B. Pearson, refused to sign the UN Genocide Convention because, as the UN then defined it, Canada was guilty of genocide.  The U.S. refused to sign it, too. Both countries pressured the UN to CHANGE its definition.  It did.  Pearson still refused to sign, likely because he was told that kids weren't just abused. They were murdered. Genocide's definition includes systematically removing people from their homes and family and forcibly detained. RCMP did that. Deliberate exposure to disease occurred in schools. Sterilization, forced abortions, medical experiments happened in hospitals. "Allegedly"?  There are too many witnesses in too many places...

If you have the courage--and that's what it takes--read Hidden From History, written and compiled by Kevin Annette, who brought all this to the public's attention in the mid 1990s. Read the UN's definition--its there, too.

Comment: My family's Oregon Trail fears were disease, starvation, getting lost, and their biggest fear.... the Mormons.  They were terrified of them as they moved through that part of the country on their  journey.  There had been raids on wagon trains by bands of Mormons, lots of threats and intimidation, some violence.  Their fears appeared to be justified several years later by the Mountain Medows Massacre.  The only time they expressed fear of Native Americans was when they came upon the body of one, shot by settlers.  They were very concerned that they would be blamed for it by the local tribes and left the area as soon as possible.

Violence is often met with violence, sometimes out of necessity and often becomes self-perpetuating.  But the true horror stories of the tribes in southern Oregon began when they have essentially been defeated.  We had our own "Trail of Tears" here.  People can justify it ( you certainly try) but it was a shameful part of our history.

Comment: Govt should set it up but the funding should come from regular payroll deductions from the employee, not from govt - i.e. build upon CPP. 
In the past, up until the 80s or so, people used to have a part of their pay set aside for retirement - they never saw the money, it was just set aside in a pension fund. When they retired, that money funded their retirement with a guaranteed income. 
Up until the 1980s, Canadians saved an average of 20% of income every week - they just didn't see that money. Today, Canadians save an average of 2.5% of their pay for retirement. 
For all the complaints about PS pensions, they put 15-20% of every pay cheque into their pension fund. That is the money used to pay their pensions. Those pensions are not paid from tax $ but from those savings and investment returns.
Banks will oppose any regulation that sets up pensions for ALL Canadians because they make billions every year from our RRSPs, far more than they could make in pension plans

Comment: Okay, THIS is where the homeless cease to have anymore humane feelings and sentiment from me. Enuff!
I (my family) was homeless for a year during (my sophomore year?) high school. So I know about homelessness, and is partly why I am so hard on them folks. Been there done that got the shirt.
Homeless today just p155 me off!
When I was homeless we did it "right". We camped. We didn't squat. We tried not to outlive our welcome anywhere and we tried to minimize our footprint. My dad and I maintained jobs (me, part time while in school), I managed to grad highschool on time. My siblings stayed in school. My mom ran all kinds of other live chores during the day.
We got camping permits and camped at designated spots. When sites weren't available we slept in our cars. We put our belongings into storage - not lugged em to the beach with us! We did'nt tap water/wires. We didn't have TVs, dogs. We cooked on coleman camping stove. We CAMPED our way thru homelessness.
We didn't SQUAT. Screw em now!

Comment: What you have with guns and suicidal individuals is a combination that ups the likelihood of death.  

First off, self-inflicted gunshot wounds are the most effective ways of killing oneself.  A Harvard study from 2001 found that 85% of those who attempted suicide this way were successful.  Suffocation (hanging) came in second at 69%.  All other methods were well below 50%.

Second the availability of guns increases the likelihood of attempting suicide.  It's quick and requires little pre-planning.  Guns play an outsized role in spontaneous suicides.  Someone in a momentary crisis situation with a tendency toward depression and perhaps under the influence of alcohol or drugs grabs a gun and it's over.  A noose requires work,  other means lead to prolonged periods between initiating the attempt and death, which gives time for an intervention or for the suicidal person to seek help.

2/3 of our gun deaths are suicides.  It's not anti-gun to acknowledge this and seek to fix it.

Comment: Two factors will push gas private vehicles off the road.  One is ghg emissions and the other is declining availability and increasing real cost of oil.   Take your pick but in 15 years, both should be putting the squeeze on the ICE car.

Oil is absolutely critical and irreplaceable for several key sectors.  Private personal transport vehicles isn't one of them.  Agriculture, goods transport, mining, military and air transport can't operate without oil.  By comparison, personal transport is both non-critical and easy to electrify even with today's technology.

So EVs are in the future even for people who currently regard them as the second coming of communism.

Cheers,
John Meyer

Comment: Cont'd - 
.
Setting an internalisation price is not always the best of the market-based mechanisms (although in the case of carbon, it probably is).
.
An arbitrary price may be the wrong price.  It may appear simple, but compliance might be achieved more economically efficiently by allowing lower-cost compliers to dominate.  This is what cap-and-trade does comparatively well.
.
The most common problem with cap-and-trade is to start with too many permits, such that the market clearing price for permits is too low, and (as in Germany with coal) actually incentivizes the activity that is supposed to be discouraged.
.
Cap-and-trade is essentially musical chairs.  Over time you are supposed to reduce the number of permits, so that the auction price rises, progressively deterring the activity.
.
But political pressures generally cause far too many permits to be issued originally, to lessen the belly-aching of those who complain (again, as happened with coal in Germany.)

(cont'd)

GM bailout was $51B ($11.3B loss), Chrysler was $12.5B ($1.3B loss), not including the first Chrylser bailout.
.

As far as the $465M loan that Tesla got from DOE - they paid it off early.  As part of the same program Ford got $5.9B to improve fuel efficiency and to produce electric vehicles. .

Comment: Jeff,

Our Governments for decades encouraged Canadian enterprises to build trade relationships outside North America but those enterprises have been slow to follow through.  This pattern of neglect of off-shore markets was endemic in many industries despite Governments' efforts to smooth the way for Canadian entrepreneurs.

The US is now targeting about 8% of their domestic market for recapture from Canadian softwood exporters (i.e. the difference between current exports and the 25% market share that the US relies on Canada to supply).  The Canadian industry will have a couple of rough years.

We're destined to repeat the many earlier cycles of questionable tariffs, rehashing earlier litigation before WHO arbitration panels, favorable panel rulings followed by Canadian countervailing duties, new bilateral agreements.  

Building other softwood foreign markets during this period will improve both our negotiating position with the US and the longer term industry stability.

Comment: This law change is all well and good, assuming it comes to pass. However, what we really, really, really need is actual traffic law enforcement. It has been shown time and again, both in practice and in theory, that it is not the size of the penalty that changes behavior but the certainty of being caught doing something "wrong".

I'd much rather see a bill to assess the effectiveness of police traffic law enforcement by randomly looking at the relative lawfulness of motor vehicle operators' behavior. Just look at a few roads and intersections and tabulate the percent of motorists who are not speeding, leaving their lanes or violating the traffic control devices (very low locally) and tie the pay of the top third of the agency responsible for enforcement to those numbers. 

If we did so, Chief Kerns might have to move into the Mission since our low rate of traffic law compliance might mean that he is paid zero dollars.

Comment: I have an intuition -- I have not researched it, nor am I aware of any studies that have addressed it -- that the difference that Vatican II made with respect to clerical sexual abuse has less to do with the frequency of abuse and more to do with the willingness of victims and their families to confront it. Stated differently, I think the generation of Catholics who entered the 1980s as adults and as parents had been formed in a Vatican II ecclesiology which taught that they had rights and duties as members of the church. If they were still deferential to the clergy, they were less so that their parents were; if priests were still on a pedestal, the pedestal was lower and the parents of victims were willing to take down the priests who harmed their children. The post-Vatican II parents were less willing than earlier generations to go away in silence. Vatican II taught them to think and act as adults in the church, and many of them took that teaching seriously.

Comment: The 'truth.' You hear ignorant, narrow minded people misuse that word, consistently. You use it as though it's a universal fact upon which you can rely, which is indisputable. It's a term that brooks no opposition.

Instead, the inquiring open mind -- the mind based on scientific principles -- seeks out 'facts.' Facts aren't based on a person's emotional bias or beliefs; they exist or they don't.

There is no 'truth' about the villages. There are facts subject to statistical analysis, the analysis subject to interpretation based on other facts and knowledge. 'Truth' is simplistic and belies more complex, nuanced understanding.

'Truth' is the refuge of those incapable of critical thinking. You'll never hear a scientist or anyone versed in dealing with facts (lawyers, doctors among many others) talk about 'truth.'

Comment: The Syrian refugees' problems with immigrating to Canada are no different than the immigrants of many cultures before them.  Years ago, I managed a garment factory. Comment: I'm not sure I would go as far as saying it's been more conservative but it has been a pendulum state. We were among the first states, if not THE first, to legalize abortion in the 1960s. Dick Lamm I think was the sponsor. 

The Republicans of the late 19th Century here were split down the middle when the nation dropped silver coinage and fed the Panic of 1893, which for us was almost as bad as the Great Depression. YOu ended up with the Silver Republicans and the most prominent Republican in the state, Sen. Henry Teller, joined the rump party and finally switched parties to finish up as a Democrat. But we also had hard right politicos like Sen. Rice Means, said to have been in the Klan (but in Denver in the 1920s, who wasn't?), Sen. Lawrence Phipps and others.

Comment: Let me help you with something, my fellow Canadians:  Canada is a country, a sovereign, self-governing confederation in the Parliamentary tradition.  It is not animal, vegetable, or mineral.  It is an outline on a map, and a set of documents, and a whole lot of unique, free, opinionated people.  It is not in itself an animate object.  It does not "want to talk" about anything.  It does not have an opinion, or an agenda, or any of the other things that humans have special brains for.  It is not "yours" or "mine" or "theirs".  It doesn't belong to you, me, or anyone, even its senior First Nations partners.  You belong to it.  Are you with me?

So, when someone starts talking about "what Canada wants", or "what Canadians want", you know at least one thing:  1) either an insult is coming, from a person or fake-person who has contempt for Canada or Canadians;  or 2) it won't be what Canadians want, it'll be what she/he/it/they want, and you're not a Canadian if you don't want it, too.

Comment: New York State conducted an extensive study on high-volume slickwater hydraulic fracturing ("fracking") in 2014.  It concluded that the knowns and unknowns together posed too great a risk to public health so they placed an indefinite ban on the practice.  Industry of course will call fowl, but the science is pretty solid and recent studies on induced earthquakes should be even more worrisome to Alaskans.  Here's a link to the NY Health Department study:  http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2014/12/18/nyregion/new-york-state-fracking-report.html

Comment: Having been stuck fulfilling my Sunday duty at Our Lady of Guadalupe near the convention center I know what you mean about liturgy in your area.  Maybe I should screenshot this and send it to the local clerics.

Comment: "Residential schools were barbaric and a stain on Canada's history. But they bore no resemblance to the death camps..."

And you know that, how, exactly?  Others might--have have--debated the point.  If you've got the stomach for it, read Hidden From History, the Canadian Holocaust.  The term holocaust is not used lightly. Much of the book is dedicated to examining the many parallels.  

Back when Lester Pearson was Secretary of State for External Affairs, the UN gave our Nobel Peace prize winner the opportunity to sign off on its definition of genocide.  Pearson declined to sign. The US didn't sign it either, likely for the same reason: the UN's definition, in many ways, described what had happened to Native peoples in both countries. Instead, what Pearson and others did, was coerce the UN into narrowing --changing--the definition. STILL isn't signed to this day.

Can't believe this?  WON'T believe this?  Sure.  It's called Wilful disbelief.  Canada is still working through it.

Comment: Clearly you don't understand the business model for PZA.

Comment: Eisenhower's choice for Chief Justice (and Brennan for associate) helped a great deal, but the court was already indisposed to McCarthy when Warren was appointed.

Although King never publicly supported a political party or candidate for president, in a letter to a civil rights supporter in October 1956 he said that he was undecided as to whether he would vote for Adlai Stevenson or Dwight Eisenhower, but that "In the past I always voted the Democratic ticket." In his autobiography, King says that in 1960 he privately voted for Democratic candidate John F. Kennedy: "I felt that Kennedy would make the best president. I never came out with an endorsement. My father did, but I never made one." King adds that he likely would have made an exception to his non-endorsement policy for a second Kennedy term, saying "Had President Kennedy lived, I would probably have endorsed him in 1964."

Comment: You should do your homework before making profoundly ignorant statements in public. My Chickasaw mother was born in Snow, Oklahoma at the height of the dust bowl era, and knew third world poverty. In an act of desperation my grandma and her 12 kids thumbed a ride to Oregon coming here destitute to look for work. My mother grew up in a one room dirt floor shanty. My mother went to work fulltime when she was 13 so she could finish high school. In those days a public education was worth fighting for. My mother scrimped and saved to send me to England, to live with my legal immigrant father's family so I could attend school as she could no longer ignore the absolute incompetence of Oregon public schools. To further address your ignorance, I live well below the federal poverty level. All 3 of my children went to college because I made damn sure they had an education. As for your profound stupidity, I'll point out the obvious, Singapore has already shown you how it's done.

Comment: This article lacks logic.The United States, which is a society, must have some form of glue or foundation to function properly. A society is a community, nation, or broad grouping of people having common traditions, institutions, and collective activities and interests. Furthermore, a society's members must speak the same language for clear communication purposes. The United States is a country that welcomes legal immigration and diversity as long as those members of the society respect and adapt to the foundational structure. It is like a United States citizen moving to Japan. The expectation of living in Japan would be to learn the Japanese language and adapt to Japanese culture. If one cannot adapt, they should not be there. It is true that people have many different personalities and characteristics, but for a society to thrive and protect its members, there must be a certain level of conformity. The fabric of traditional American society is being undermined; thus we see unrest.

Comment: No. The second example shows us that you're talking straight out of your bottom.

There was no "Alfred Langdon." The Langdon clinic  is calling.

http://www.uh.edu/engines/epi1199.htm

Gallup brought science to that process. Richard Smith tells how, by the time Landon challenged Roosevelt, the prestigious Literary Digest magazine was America's leading pollster. The Digest featured a regular poll called "America Speaks." It drew samples from phone books and auto registrations. Gallup knew that such samples were biased toward people with means. I remember life in those days: not everyone could afford cars or phones. My parents, who had both, strongly supported the Republican Landon.

So the Digest predicted a solid victory for Landon. Using a far smaller, far better sample, Gallup predicted Roosevelt's victory. He did more than that. He also showed why the Digest's flawed methods predicted Landon would win. In the wake of that, the Digest folded up, and Gallup became America's oracle.

Comment: I'm all for Uber and/or Lyft to start working up here, because needless to say, our Taxi situation isn't great.... but that said, the Senate majority did the whole State a massive disservice by refusing to consider amendment after amendment that would have eeked out a little more protection for Alaskans. For example, there is no requirement for Uber/Lyft drivers to have an Alaska driver's license! No requirement for their car to be registered in Alaska! There's no provision for Workmen's Compensation for the drivers! 

And to top it all off, the bill is utterly toothless, as the Finance Committee stripped out all the language allowing the Dept. of Commerce to do anything. So, sure, there's a requirement for insurance on the vehicle, etc, but there's nothing behind that requirement. No insurance? No problem. 

We have to hope that the House Majority takes a critical look at this and adds back in some sorely needed bones.

Comment: 72,000 wild horses and burros. According to who, exactly?
So many holes in this argument, it's difficult to know where to begin.
You're aware, aren't you, that wild horses and burros are biological entities, subject to the same frailties as deer, moose, elk, etc? 
For example - a severe, five year long drought? During which time, apparently, even with a lack of water and forage, they still managed to triple their populations, subsisting on sand and sagebrush.
Of the thousands of infants born in a season, 50% will not survive to their first birthday. Not a BLM declaration, of course. This is the result of several independent reports. But as hard as it is for the Bureau, et al, to accept, wild horses and burros absolutely DO die. To the tune of at least 10- and in years of environmental catastrophe - 25% mortality.
The higher the population, the more animals die. 
Maybe before stringing them up, en masse, a little verification outside the BLM box might be in order?

Comment: The straw man argument that re-conveyance was touted as “the cure” misses the point. For over ten years DNR was not upholding their legal obligation to harvest Clallam owned timber, resulting in loss of revenue to the county and it’s junior taxing districts. For most of those ten years the Clallam County Board of Commissioners had a Democratic majority and the majority chose not to get DNR to uphold their legal obligation to the county. Progress on the issue was not made until Republicans Jim McEntire and Bill Peach joined the Board of Natural resources and pressed the issue with DNR. The idea of re-conveyance was considered an option, not a cure, should DNR fail to address the arrearage. Due to Republican efforts, DNR is now working the way it should and revenue is flowing to the county. Since DNR is doing their job, re-conveyance is not necessary.

Comment: The process for selection of a Grand Master of the Order is specified in its Constitutional Charter and the Order's Code.  The supreme head of the Order is the Grand Master, who is elected for life by the Council Complete of State and is in no way subject to the Holy Father nor does he derive his authority in any way from the Holy See.

Therefore the Holy Father cannot remove Matthew Festing.

The Patron's position relative to the Knights is roughly equivalent to a secular ambassador to a country. He promotes the spiritual interests of the Order and its relations with the Holy See.

The Holy Father can remove the Patron at will. However, the Patron cannot interfere in the internal governance of the Order.

Comment: There's two issues here:
1.) Is Eugene's sign code so onerous that it burdens our First Amendment rights? 
2.) Does complaint-driven code enforcement work?

I'll leave the first issue to the lawyers, although it seems that a strong case can be made that it at least places unnecessary burdens on our right to express ourselves.

On the second, it leaves us with a city that doesn't enforce its own laws except in rare cases. This makes people feel singled out when enforcement is directed at them and also makes it nigh on impossible to mount a challenge that changes the code, since it affects almost no one (even when many are violating it).

Who's going to call in the contractor neighbor who built a liveable "shed" in his back yard? Sure, it's sub-code by definition since it didn't get the permits that are required, but the city's ability to keep complaints anonymous isn't to be trusted, so there goes your relationship.

If we're going to have laws, let's have workable enforcement.

Comment: This article really misses the mark. The flooding in Houston, in this case, had nothing to do with storm surge and everything to do with drainage. For this type of event drainage would have needed to be designed for 500+ year flooding and 30 inches of rain in a 36 hour period. And across several cities and all linking to the ocean, just not feasible.   Houston area communities do a very good job designing for drainage in this area, as does TxDOT,  but without tearing out the older systems and replacing them at an enormous cost, it will never be sufficient to handle this type of event. Imagine if this had happened in any other US coastal area, now imagine it happening in NYC...it gets so much worse. I was in Central America when Hurricane Mitch did this in 1998.  Around 20,000 people died and 2.5 million homeless. Maybe it isn't fair to compare Central America to the US, but I think it helps with scale. Houston's need of a surge protection  system is real, but its not why we flooded.

Comment: "...signs of cognitive and memory impairment, for example, uncharacteristic irrationality, confusion and distress...One does not need to be a medical professional to recogconize (sic) these indicators of dementia".
Indeed! One does not need to be a medical professional to make that mistaken diagnosis.
In fact, "signs of cognitive and memory impairment, for example, uncharacteristic irrationality, confusion and distress" - i.e. delirium -can be the result of a severe illness and infection in an otherwise cognitive intact person. For example Pneumonia or an UTI. Could even be seen in a normal young person in the 24 hour post-operative period.
I have met patients with dementia who have been quite lucid, rational, and calm. Just their time frame is out of whack. Example: one patient told me that she didn't want her son to marry the girl he was dating. The son said: "It's too late now - we've been married for 35 years!".
Unfortunately it's a common mistake to confuse delirium with dementia.

Comment: Alli: Sure, everything becomes moist backpacking in the rain...takes great care to stay reasonably dry. I use neoprene fisherman's gloves...thickest I can find and sized very large because, when wet, they are tough to put on and remove. They will get wet but keep me somewhat warm. That keeps my other gloves dry. I use a two-layer system. Old, worn-out Gore Tex type shells for parka and pants...with a thin, less breathable rain parka and pants shell over that. Seems to wick away body moisture. Idea is not the get the inner shell wet before putting on the real rain gear. I use gaiters to keep rain and drips from wet brush out of my boots. My tarp tent has no floor...wet at first but dries out eventually. I can wear my wet boots inside...and the dog can come in if she wants. I pack all rain gear for easy availability...zippers unzipped, etc. Because, when it starts to rain it can come quickly and soak everything while the pack is open and I am fumbling around. Yes, get out no matter what.

Comment: the revolution of 1893 was not an overthrow of the Polynesian peoples, but a change in the form of government, which the Polynesian people immediately embraced Even Liluokalani wrote in her diary in 1900 "Tho for a moment it (the overthrow) cost me a pang for my people(Polynesians) it was only momentary, for the present has a hope for the future of my people". Remember Hawaii had become a U.S. Territory. When Liliuokalani died she was flying a U.S. flag outside her Washington Place home. 
Or, how about the radical Polynesian-Hawaiian Robert Wilcox, who also said in 1900, "The question of restoration of the Monarchy is gone forever. We are now a people, however, that can vote. You all know we have two-thirds of the votes in this country...If you want to rule, it is for you to decide". 
Polynesian-Hawaiians had the largest voting block, and the most representation in the Territorial Legislature up until the 1940s, but still are a voting block that victimizing politicians go after today.

Comment: Fossil fuels are a non-renewable resource. Also, flying is an interesting topic. Global aviation accounts for 2% of emissions; vehicles and ships account for 15%.  Planes have been working steadily on their fuel efficiency issues since the '70s and it's had an impact. If the celebrities would give up private jets and go economy class, you'd see an even greater drop in energy-per-human cost. By contrast, we're doing more solo driving. The issue is whether people recognize it's a problem and act accordingly to do what they can do today. Obviously, a family in a rural area may not be able to give up a car. But in my city, many more people could. It's laughable when I see some hulking SUV occupied by a lone well-heeled suburbanite emerge from a downtown parking garage onto a tiny street where most people are walking. Instead, she could park at the end of the line and take the subway.

Comment: I wouldn't be sorry to see a crash but I don't think a lack of sales indicates a crash or even a slump. Lack of sales can simply be lack of inventory. Lack of inventory can come from a lot of things but here is one I haven't seen mentioned anywhere. Much of the purchasing the last few years is foreign money - perhaps 30-40% of the houses in Burnaby are now owned by foreign money. These were bought before the new tax so if someone wants to sell and buy another place here then on top of the realtor's fees and property transfer tax they are going to have to pay another 15%. So there is increased incentive to just stay put - especially if you are buying as an investment rather than a home. So the 15% foreign buyer tax is actually acting to prevent sales of homes already owned by foreign buyers - lowering inventory and sales. But that doesn't mean the market is crashing.
